metadata.synopsis: A divid bard has assisted Withers in providing music for the evening. The player can speak with them to change the music that is playing during the epilogue.

15.speaker: Milil
15.text: Oh, hello. Let me guess, you've got some suggestions about the music choice?
15.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warilyNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warily

130.speaker: Player
130.text: The music's fine, uninvited guests are not. Who are you?

18.speaker: Player
18.text: You seem glum - I thought bards were meant to be full of pep and joy.

87.speaker: Milil
87.text: I find it hard to summon up the trademark pep these days.

188.speaker: Milil
188.text: You have no idea who I am, do you? I thought Withers might have set the stage a little.

121.speaker: Milil
121.text: I owe him a 'favour' - one he is eternally invoking.

5.speaker: Milil
5.text: I thought 'honouring the worthy' was a fair price to pay for Withers to pull me out the Fugue Plane. Alas - one purgatory to another.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: What were you doing in the Fugue Plane?

95.speaker: Milil
95.text: Languishing in obscurity. Cyric knew what he was doing when he punished me for that song - the prick.

78.speaker: Milil
78.text: Before I was banished to the Fugue Plane, I had song-prayers coming out the proverbial ears. Guess how many I get now? None.

7.speaker: Milil
7.text: ... Apologies. I think I got a mote carried away there. You're hardly to blame; you just want to change up the music, I wager.

74.speaker: Narrator
74.text: *Musical prayers were once offered to Milil, Lord of Song - a minor deity whose worship faded after offending the trickster god Cyric.*

36.speaker: Player
36.text: I think you're being a bit dramatic - this is hardly purgatory.

175.speaker: Milil
175.text: Hm. Perhaps I've not sufficiently explained my - ah, predicament.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: I disagree. It's an honour to be serenaded by Milil, Lord of Song.

75.speaker: Player
75.text: Even mind flayers appreciate a good tune - it's an honour to meet the Lord of Song.

105.speaker: Milil
105.text: You... You know? You're bloody right - it IS an honour!
105.context: CinematicNodeContext: absoutely elated that he's been recognisedNodeContext: starts shocked, then turns to absoutely elated that he's been recognised

47.speaker: Milil
47.text: FINALLY! The Scribe picks an adventurer of substance - of culture! What can I do you for?

144.speaker: Player
144.text: It's an honour to meet the noble Lord of Song - even if I'm no bard.

170.speaker: Player
170.text: Either your ambition or your talent failed - which was it?

151.speaker: Milil
151.text: No amount of ambition or talent can save you from the whims of a greater god, Gale Dekarios.
151.context: NodeContext: a bit more serious, slightly rueful

169.speaker: Milil
169.text: You would do well to remember that - and I would do well to return to my music. Have a good evening.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: Wait, it's all coming back to me. I know who you are - what an honour!

145.speaker: Player
145.text: I'd like you to play a different song, please.

101.speaker: Milil
101.text: Go on then - what should I play?

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Can you play a pretty song, reminiscent of taverns and tales?

40.speaker: Player
40.text: Something lively that encourages dancing would be perfect.

72.speaker: Milil
72.text: Fantastic idea - it'll suit the whole affair perfectly.

140.speaker: Milil
140.text: Very well - be on your way, make merry, and music shall follow you!

122.speaker: Milil
122.text: Fine - it's your party, after all.

157.speaker: Milil
157.text: Curious choice for such an occasion - but I am merely the tune-plucker. So it shall be.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: I'd like something that feels rich and warm.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: Something nostalgic and gentle would be ideal.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Do you have any new compositions? Something that's never been heard before?

165.speaker: Player
165.text: I'd like to dedicate a song to a lost friend.

52.speaker: Milil
52.text: A dedication to the noble dead - that's a bit more like it! Proper barding, that. Who are you remembering?

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Gale Dekarios - the bravest man I ever met.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: Karlach. She was the brightest light that ever burned.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: I killed a bard called Alfira against my will. She deserves remembering.

174.speaker: Player
174.text: My friend Wyll was dragged to the Hells.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: A spirit called Hope died in Avernus trying to save me.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: Sing a song of Balduran, if you would.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: He's not dead, but gone for now. A mind flayer called the Emperor saved the world.

193.speaker: Player
193.text: I've changed my mind - a normal song will do.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: Actually, what you were playing before was perfect.

131.speaker: Milil
131.text: Fantastical news - carry on I shall!

149.speaker: Milil
149.text: Suppose I'll get back to it then.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: In that case, I'll leave you in quiet to your terrible fate.

155.speaker: Player
155.text: Go on then - what's your name?

35.speaker: Milil
35.text: Milil. Though if the lack of song-prayers is anything to go by, that name carries less weight than it used to.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: I know exactly who you are - it's such an honour.

77.speaker: Milil
77.text: No, no - I can see it all over your face. You've not a clue who I am.
77.context: NodeContext: Feeling a little sorry for himself

179.speaker: Player
179.text: What a shame - I'd like to hear a different song, please.

189.speaker: Player
189.text: You know what? I'll just leave you to play.

81.speaker: Player
81.text: Mind if I play along with you?

137.speaker: Player
137.text: That's a poor tone to take with the God of Ambition.

14.speaker: Milil
14.text: Ahhh yes - the new one. Withers told me about you. A fresh god... Feels good, doesn't it?

11.speaker: Player
11.text: Better than I could've ever imagined.

84.speaker: Milil
84.text: Yes, I remember it well. Back in my day the worship flowed like wine: rich, unctuous. Satiating.

64.speaker: Milil
64.text: Before I was forced to take an extended break in the Fugue Plane, of course.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Forgive me, were you a god before?

187.speaker: Milil
187.text: Technically still am. But where I once held every song ever written in my heart, now I'm... well.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: I best be on my way.

57.speaker: Player
57.text: It's more responsibility than I was ready for.

172.speaker: Milil
172.text: I know how you feel. I had to hold every song, half-rhyme and muddled tune in my heart for a while.

9.speaker: Player
9.text: What could you know of godhood?

126.speaker: Milil
126.text: I knew of godhood before you knew your first cantrip, wizard. I knew it all very intimately - I was favoured among the pantheon, even.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: You playing a different song would feel even better.

118.speaker: Player
118.text: Actually, I would like to hear a different song.

44.speaker: Milil
44.text: The solitary adventurer approaches once more - lonely, are we? Wishing for more melancholic music?
44.context: NodeContext: stops playing his lyre to be rude to the player

139.speaker: Player
139.text: I didn't ask earlier - what were you doing in the Fugue Plane?

104.speaker: Player
104.text: Even if you're an arse, it's still an honour to hear the Lord of Song play.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: I wished to pay respects to the noble Lord of Song - it's an honour.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I'd like you to change the song.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: Nothing, carry on as you were.

1.speaker: Milil
1.text: You know, I was most rude earlier. In many ways, the solitary road is the most noble path one can walk.
1.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lyre and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasmNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lyre and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasm

0.speaker: Milil
0.text: How may my music be of assistance?

58.speaker: Milil
58.text: The skeleton told me I was performing for a 'party of the ages' - I expected a few more attendees.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Who are you to have such high expectations?

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Withers is hiring bards? Glad to see my money put to good use.

82.speaker: Milil
82.text: Hah! I've never pried a coin from his cold, dead hands. No - I regrettably owe him a favour.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: I expected some better music - can you change the song?

111.speaker: Milil
111.text: Look, Withers isn't paying me enough - or at all - to be abiding a violent audience. Strike me again and I'm gone.
111.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warilyNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warily

134.speaker: Player
134.text: I'm sorry! It won't happen again.

37.speaker: Milil
37.text: It better not. Now, what can I do for you?

114.speaker: Milil
114.text: I really expected better behaviour from you. Truly. Strike me again and I shall have to leave.
114.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warilyNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player a little warily

127.speaker: Milil
127.text: Come now - out with it! Would be a shame to leave a party like this bereft of music too long.
127.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player with light disgustNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player with light disgust

112.speaker: Player
112.text: I didn't ask earlier - what were you doing in the Fugue Plane?

164.speaker: Player
164.text: It's just an honour to hear the Lord of Song play such beautiful music.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: I wished to pay respects to the noble Lord of Song - it's an honour.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: I'd like you to change the song.

79.speaker: Milil
79.text: Your wish is my et cetera - what song do you want?

192.speaker: Player
192.text: Nothing, carry on as you were.

132.speaker: Milil
132.text: Ah, the worshipful and cultured God of Ambition himself! How may I help?
132.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lyre and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasmNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lyre and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasm

100.speaker: Player
100.text: Can I play along with you?

69.speaker: Milil
69.text: Why not! I'll set a tempo, you join at your leisure - provided you know your way around an instrument.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: It'd be an honour to play along with you, if I may.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: Nothing, please carry on as you were.

158.speaker: Milil
158.text: Greetings, oh cultured adventurer! What can I do you for?
158.context: CinematicNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasmNodeContext: Milil stops playing his lute and looks to the player with excitement and enthusiasm
